Hello Michael, 


>Private methods are difficult to test because, after all=
, they're
>private. If you adopt a convention that API methods are only pre=
sented
>via Java Interfaces instead of concrete classes then you don't care=

>about the way the implementers of the Interfaces are written. You can
>th=
en make non-API methods within the concrete implementation public
>without =
implying that they are themselves API methods. 

I am not sure I follow, bu=
t as I can see this only works if you never plan to extend your clases, or =
leave them to be extended. I guess that in your case only thing visible fro=
m the outside are interfaces. If you write frameworks, it is difficult to g=
et by without inheritance. Inheritance breaks encapsulation, keeping method=
s private helps encapsulate things. 
Also, I am not shure what you mean by =
"without implying", generally you "make statement" with your code, any othe=
r method yo imply something (comments, documentation etc...) is superfluous=
.

Regards,

Danijel Arsenovski
subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods, its urgent
